columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to answer the following questions by applying the concept of capital budgeting.
**Capital budgeting** is the concept of determining the cost of a project or investment.  The difference between the cost and the market value of the investment is called the **net present value**.

We are given the following data:
- There is a proposed expansion of an existing subsidiary located in Switzerland.
- Cost of expansion is SF 13.8 million.
- The cash flow from the project is SF 3.9 million for 5 years.
- The dollar required return is 12% per year.

Additionally, we are given the following data
- The spot rate is SF 1.09.
- The going rate on Eurodollars is 5% per year.
- The going rate on Euroswiss is 4% per year

## a.

We are asked to determine the exchange rate over the next four years.

Let us compute the exchange rate for Year 1, Year 2, Year 3, and Year 4. The formula for the determining the exchange rate is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{t})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^t\\\
\end{aligned}$$

wherein: 

$E(S_{t})$ = Expected exchange rate in *t* periods 

$S_{0}$ = Current spot exchange rate  

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in foreign country 

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate in the U.S.

First, we will determine the exchange rate for year 1:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{1})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(0.04-0.05)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.01)}]^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times( 0.99)^1\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times0.99\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{SF 1.0791}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 1 is **SF 1.0791 per $ 1**.

Next, we will determine the exchange rate for year 2:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{2})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(0.04-0.05)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.01)}]^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times( 0.99)^2\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times0.9801\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{SF 1.0683}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 2 is **SF 1.0683 per $ 1**.

Next, we will determine the exchange rate for year 3:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{3})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(0.04-0.05)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.01)}]^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times( 0.99)^3\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times0.9703\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{SF 1.0576}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 3 is **SF 1.0576 per $ 1**.

Next, we will determine the exchange rate for year 4:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{4})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^4\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(0.04-0.05)}]^4\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.01)}]^4\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times( 0.99)^4\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times0.9606\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{SF 1.0470}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 4 is **SF 1.0470 per $ 1**.

Lastly, we will determine the exchange rate for year 5:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$E(S_{5})$} &=\text{$S_{0}$}\times[ 1+\text{($R_{FC}$-$R_{US}$)}]^5\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(0.04-0.05)}]^5\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times[ 1+\text{(-0.01)}]^5\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times( 0.99)^5\\[10pt]
&=\text{SF 1.09}\times0.9510\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{SF 1.0366}}
\end{aligned}$$
 

The exchange rate in Year 5 is **SF 1.0366 per $ 1**.
As we can see, the Euroswiss rate is *less than* the Eurodollar rate. As a result, the exchange rate for the next four years are **decreasing.**

## b.

We are asked onvert the projected franc flows into dollar flows
and calculate the NPV.

To determine the NPV, we will use the **home currency approach** of international capital budgeting. In home currency approach, we will convert all the foreign currency into the home currency, and apply the discount rate to determine the NPV.

We have already computed the exchange rate for the next 5 years in the previous question. To summarize:

<center>

| |Exchange Rate | 
|--|:--:| 
|Year 1| SF 1.0791| 
|Year 2 | SF 1.0683| 
| Year 3| SF 1.0576 | 
|Year 4 | SF 1.0470| 
| Year 5 | SF 1.0366| 

</center>

Next, we will divide the expected cash flow per year by the expected exchange rate to determine the cash flow in U.S. dollars.  To visualize:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Cash Flow in \$} &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in SF }}{\text{Exchange Rate}}\\[10pt]

\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have converted the expected cash flows into dollars. We need to divide it to the discount rate of 13% so we can get the  present value. The formula is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value } &= \dfrac{\text{Cash Flow in \$ }}{\text{(1 + Discount Rate)}^t}\\[10pt]

\end{aligned}$$

We will now combine the present value from Year 1 to Year 5.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Present Value Y1}&&\$ 3,226,896\\
\text{Present Value Y2}&&2,910,284\\
\text{Present Value Y3}&&2,624,810\\
\text{Present Value Y4}&&2,367,288\\
\text{Present Value Y5}&&\underline{~~~~2,134,841}\\
\text{Total Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{\$ 13,264,119}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Lastly, we will subtract the cost of expansion worth $ 12,660,550 from the present value to get the **net present value**.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Total Present Value}&&\$ 13,264,119\\
\text{Cost of Expansion}&&\underline{(12,660,550)}\\
\text{Net Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{~~~~~~~\$ 603,569}}}\\
\end{array}$$
As a conclusion, the net present value (NPV) of the expansion is **$ 603,569** applying the concept of home currency approach.

## c.

We are asked to determine the required return on franc flows and determine the NPV in francs and then convert to dollars.

We will determine the required return on franc flows using the concept of **foreign currency approach**. In this approach,  we will determine first the required return on foreign investment. After, we will discount it foreign cash flow to determine the NPV in foreign currency. Lastly, we will convert the foreign NPV to dollar NPV.

First, we will determine the difference in the nominal rates using the international Fisher effect. The **international Fisher effect** is a theory stating the real interest rates **are the same** between countries.

The formula of international Fisher effect is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$R_{US}$}-\text{$h_{US}$} &=\text{$R_{FC}$}-\text{$h_{FC}$}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S.

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country

$h_{FC}$ = Inflation rate in a foreign country

$h_{US}$ = Inflation rate in a U.S.

Since what we are looking for is the required return in Swiss franc, we need to derived the formula as follows: 


$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{$R_{Fc}$} &=\text{$R_{US}$}-\text{$h_{US}$}+\text{$h_{FC}$}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$R_{US}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of U.S.

$R_{FC}$ = Nominal risk-free rate of a foreign country

$h_{FC}$ = Inflation rate in a foreign country

$h_{US}$ = Inflation rate in a U.S.

We will now combine the present value from Year 1 to Year 5.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Present Value Y1}&&\text{SF 3,513,514}\\
\text{Present Value Y2}&&3,165,327\\
\text{Present Value Y3}&&2,851,646\\
\text{Present Value Y4}&&2,569,051\\
\text{Present Value Y5}&&\underline{~~~~~~~2,314,460}\\
\text{Total Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{\text{SF 14,413,998}}}\\
\end{array}$$

Lastly, we will subtract the cost of expansion worth SF 13,800,000 from the present value to get the **net present value**.

$$\begin {array}{lrr}
\text{Total Present Value}&&\text{SF 14,413,998}\\
\text{Cost of Expansion}&&\underline{~~(13,800,000)}\\
\text{Net Present Value}&&\underline{\underline{~~~~\text{SF 613,998
}}}\\
\end{array}$$
As a conclusion, the required return rate is **11%**, the NPV in Swiss franc is  **SF 613,998**, and the NPV in U.S. dollars is **$ 563,301**.
As a conclusion, we have determined the NPV using the home currency approach and foreign currency approach.
